abstract.text: Provide quick access to useful actions by adding context menus to your iOS app.

metadata.title: Adding context menus in your app

inlineContent.text: This sample project demonstrates how to add context menus to user-interface elements such as views, controls, table views, collection views, and web views. Apps enhance and extend context menus with actions, nested submenu actions, and custom previews. For more information on context menu design, see
This sample shows two ways to create context menus:
For a
, the sample creates a
object and attaches it to that view. The
object focuses the user’s attention on a specific portion of the UI, and provides actions for the user to perform on that content. Then, the app adopts the
protocol and provides a
object.
For more specific UI elements like tables, collections, and web views, the app adopts specific protocols for those elements that return a

specifies the view to use during animated transitions.

content.text: Add a context menu to a web view

inlineContent.text: Select the Basic test case from the sample’s Web Views outline item. When the user touches and holds on the link within the
, the app presents a
to show that link content with a set of default
items. When the user touches the view controller, the user moves out of the app and into Safari.
Select the Preview Provider test case from the sample’s Web Views outline item. When the user touches and holds on the link within the
, the app presents a custom view controller.

abstract.text: An object that provides a visible standard interface for browsing the web.
The methods for presenting native user interface elements on behalf of a webpage.
Tells the delegate that a contextual menu interaction began.
An object that displays interactive web content, such as for an in-app browser.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
A menu element that performs its action in a closure.
An object that manages an ordered collection of data items and presents them using customizable layouts.
A single data item when that item is within the collection view’s visible bounds.
The methods adopted by the object you use to manage user interactions with items in a collection view.
Returns a context menu configuration for the item at a point.
An object containing the configuration details for the contextual menu.
An interaction object that you use to display relevant actions for your content.
Creates a context menu interaction object with the specified delegate object.
The methods for providing the set of actions to perform on your content, and for customizing the preview of that content.
Returns the configuration data to use when previewing the content.
The base class for controls, which are visual elements that convey a specific action or intention in response to user interactions.
A container for grouping related menu elements in an app menu or contextual menu.
A view that presents data using rows in a single column.
The visual representation of a single row in a table view.
Methods for managing selections, configuring section headers and footers, deleting and reordering cells, and performing other actions in a table view.
Returns a context menu configuration for the row at a point.
An object describing the view to use during preview-related animations.
An object that manages the content for a rectangular area on the screen.
Adds an interaction to the view.
An object that manages a view hierarchy for your UIKit app.
Provide quick access to useful actions by adding menus and keyboard shortcuts to your Mac app built with Mac Catalyst.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Adding menus and shortcuts to the menu bar and user interface

abstract.text: Display nested views using a configurable and highly customizable layout.
Simplify interactions with your app using menu systems, contextual menus, Home Screen quick actions, and keyboard shortcuts.
Display data in a single column of customizable rows.
Present your content onscreen and define the interactions allowed with that content.
Add support for Writing Tools to your app’s text views.
